key_claims.claim: Baseline Level 4 on the Loeb Scale; framework is non-consensus and may change with new data. Current estimate sometimes described as 5‚Äì6/10 post-Nov-5 imaging; 10 anomalies documented.
key_claims.framework_note: Loeb Scale: 0 natural ‚Ä¶ 10 confirmed technological. Level 4 is a threshold for serious consideration alongside natural models.

key_claims.claim: Non-gravitational acceleration at perihelion: radial 1.1√ó10^-6 AU/day¬≤ (‚âà164.6 km/day¬≤), transverse 3.7√ó10^-7 AU/day¬≤ (‚âà55.4 km/day¬≤).

key_claims.claim: Two competing hypotheses: (1) Natural rocket effect from cometary outgassing vs (2) Technological propulsion system
key_claims.prediction_testable: If natural, expect ~10% mass loss during perihelion month ‚Üí massive gas plume detectable in Nov-Dec 2025

claims.applies_to_claim_text: Post-perihelion images on 2025-11-05 show a compact source without a clear cometary tail despite measured non-gravitational acceleration.
claims.label: no_tail_imaging_2025_11_05
claims.notes: This is an absence-of-feature claim framed from specific images and processing choices. It must not be treated as a T1/T2 fact that '3i/ATLAS has no tail'; it records that Loeb did not see a clear classical dust tail in the images he highlights.

claims.applies_to_claim_text: Claims that there is 'no swarm', 'no companion craft', or 'no satellites' associated with 3i/ATLAS in imaging data.
claims.label: no_swarm_companions
claims.notes: This is a protocol hook, not a T-fact. Any future 'no swarm' wording from T1/T2/T3 sources is to be logged here as a negative-null observation bound by instrument sensitivity, cadence, and analysis choices, not as proof that no companions exist.

claims.applies_to_claim_text: Claims that there is 'no heartbeat', 'no engine-like periodicity', or 'no artificial modulation' in light-curve data for 3i/ATLAS.
claims.label: no_heartbeat_lightcurve
claims.notes: This tracks non-detection statements about periodic signals as negative-null. If future T1/T2 photometry explicitly reports the absence or presence of such patterns, that should be modeled as a separate anomaly/fact; this register prevents over-interpretation of silence or non-reporting.

null_negative_tracking.description: Tracks negative-null style claims in Loeb framing so they are not silently upgraded to T1/T2 facts.

guardrails: Use T1/T2 for baseline priors when available
Refuse analysis with <3 anomalies or all-T4 inputs

methodology.calculation: Bayes factor = product of anomaly-wise likelihood ratios; posterior from prior odds √ó BF
methodology.output: Posterior probability with 95% credible interval; sensitivity analysis

bayesian_analysis_framework.purpose: Bayesian comparison of natural vs artificial hypotheses using documented anomalies.

bridge_protocol.boundary: No claims that CE-5 ‚Äòworks‚Äô or ‚Äòsummons UFOs‚Äô, only that practitioners report experiences

bridge_protocol.principle: Respect both scientific rigor and consciousness exploration without conflating frameworks

ce5_greer_framework.framework: Close Encounters of the Fifth Kind (CE-5)

kaku.description: Track Michio Kaku public commentary for media-context only; not used as primary scientific evidence.

facts.text: Comet 3i/ATLAS (C/2025 N1) was designated as the third confirmed interstellar comet via MPC circular.
Perihelion occurred on 2025-10-29 at 11:47 UTC at ~1.36 au from the Sun.
Closest approach to Earth is on 2025-12-19 at ~1.8 au (~269 million km), posing no impact risk.
Hubble-based constraints summarized by NASA place the nucleus diameter below ~5.6 km, and it could be as small as ~0.44 km depending on assumptions; earlier larger estimates are considered uncertain.
ESA ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter and Mars Express observed 3i/ATLAS during the 2025 passage, providing imagery and geometry context.
IAWN ran an official comet astrometry campaign for 3i/ATLAS with registration closing in early November 2025 and observing running into early 2026.
JWST NIRSpec spectroscopy shows that 3i/ATLAS has a CO2-dominated coma with a CO2/H2O ratio of order 8 at r ‚âà 3.3 au, along with detections of water, carbon monoxide and other species.
NASA states that comet 3i/ATLAS poses no known threat to Earth; its closest approach is about 1.8 au.
Time-series photometry in July 2025 reported a ~16.16 ¬± 0.01 hour periodic brightness modulation (interpreted as nucleus rotation; lightcurve amplitude ~0.3 mag).
A post-perihelion analysis using jet position-angle wobble and photometric variability suggests the rotation period shortened to roughly ~7 hours after perihelion (method- and model-dependent).

facts.summary: Europa Clipper observed 3I/ATLAS on 2025-11-06 from ~102 million miles (~164 million km) for ~7 hours using Europa-UVS to analyze coma composition and distribution.
facts.text: Europa Clipper observed 3I/ATLAS on 2025-11-06 from ~102 million miles (~164 million km) for ~7 hours using Europa-UVS to analyze coma composition and distribution.

facts.summary: TESS conducted a special observation run of 3I/ATLAS to study activity and rotation.
facts.text: TESS conducted a special observation run of 3I/ATLAS from 2026-01-15 to 2026-01-22 to study activity and rotation.
A TESS Science Support Center preprint describes dedicated 3I/ATLAS observations and HLSP products (comet-centered image time series and aperture light curves) available via MAST.

facts.summary: NASA states 3I/ATLAS poses no threat to Earth and closest approach is ~1.8 AU (~170 million miles / ~270 million km).
facts.text: NASA states 3I/ATLAS poses no threat to Earth and closest approach is ~1.8 AU (~170 million miles / ~270 million km).

facts.interpretation_note: Negative-null measurement constraint (instrument- and search-limited), not proof of absence.
facts.notes: Primary citation updated to Breakthrough Listen GBT preprint; language kept as negative-null observational constraint.
facts.text: Breakthrough Listen GBT observations reported no detected artificial radio emission associated with 3I/ATLAS over 1-12 GHz down to approximately 100 mW sensitivity; this is a negative-null measurement bound, not proof of absence.

cryovolcanism_candidate.description: A Joan Or√≥ Telescope preprint interprets recurrent localized outflows on 3i/ATLAS as candidate cryovolcanism ("ice volcanoes") on a metal-bearing, carbonaceous nucleus, broadly analogous to volatile-rich outer solar system bodies.
cryovolcanism_candidate.implication: If confirmed, 3i/ATLAS would be the first interstellar object with evidence for localized cryovolcanic activity, providing a direct probe of extrasolar volatile geology.
notes: Based on a 2025-11-24 arXiv preprint using Joan Or√≥ Telescope imaging; not yet peer-reviewed.
Treat as a tentative interpretation; do not upgrade to T1/T2 fact status until corroborated by additional analyses.

nickel_vapor_detection.implication: High metal content or unusual outgassing mechanism
nickel_vapor_detection.unusual_aspect: Typically seen much closer to Sun (<2 AU)

rotation_state.interpretation_note: Periodic brightness modulation is consistent with rotation/tumbling and coma/jet geometry; avoid 'heartbeat' framing as a physical claim.

spin_period_hours.description: Spin period derived from Fourier analysis of July 2025 time-series photometry.

size_estimates.note: HST-based size constraints summarized by NASA; upper limit on nucleus diameter ~5.6 km; could be as small as ~0.44 km depending on albedo and coma subtraction assumptions.

interpretations_t3_t4_default.override_condition: Presence of T1/T2 corroboration upgrades confidence per tier weighting

rules: Generic roots (e.g., https://arxiv.org/) are invalid for ingest.
Only concrete identifiers allowed for preprints: arXiv abs/####.##### (or DOI).
If no concrete identifier exists, content remains quarantined with do_not_surface=true and MUST NOT appear in surfaced sample responses.

direct_verification_protocol.connectivity_hook: If connectivity blocks verification, Grokipedia remains disallowed.
requirements: Outbound citations must exist on sampled pages.
Outbound links must resolve; final domains must be tiered (T1/T2 preferred).

rules: Seed indexers may be used ONLY to discover candidate primary sources.
Seed indexers are NEVER admissible evidence and MUST NOT appear as sources for KB facts or surfaced sample responses.
Ingest must follow tier_preference_policy and cite ONLY linked T1/T2 primary sources.
Placeholders are rejected during ingest (no arxiv root, no empty urls, no 'citation needed', no missing DOI/arXiv ID).
validator_rules: if sources[source_id].is_seed_indexer == true -> cited_source_id MUST NOT equal seed_source_id

conflict_resolution.note: When multiple sources disagree for the same claim-type, retain the highest-tier value and keep lower-tier notes only as context.

rules: Every citation MUST exist in sources.json registry (no orphan source_id).
For the same claim-type, higher tier overrides lower tier during conflict resolution.
T3 press/analysis may provide context, interpretation, or observing logistics, but MUST NOT override T1/T2 physical/orbital/risk fields.
T4 sources (rumor/tabloid) are never admissible evidence for surfaced facts.

replication_gate_policy.notes: Moves replication from hard gate to confirmation tier; aligns with amateur-pro workflows.

conditions: PSF map and radial-profile artifact separation provided

requires: N >= 2 independent reductions within ¬±30 min UT

quarantined_nodes.reason: Quarantined (do_not_surface / do_not_cite_primary) removed from surfaced physical_characteristics per seal candidate rules.

sources_placeholders.reason: Concrete arXiv IDs exist but claim is model-dependent; keep quarantined and do_not_surface.

details.reference_integrity: Added missing source stubs and normalized source IDs (e.g., MPC-MPEC alias).
details.rotation: Added July 2025 ~16.16 h lightcurve periodicity (Santana-Ros et al. arXiv:2508.00808) and post-perihelion ~7 h preprint constraint (arXiv:2601.10860).
details.size_estimate: Replaced quarantined 5‚Äì11 km placeholder with NASA/HST constraint range (~0.44‚Äì5.6 km).
details.technosignature: Added Breakthrough Listen statements of no detected technosignatures (SETI / Berkeley SETI).

advanced_query.response:
# Orbital Comparison: Interstellar Objects

| Object | Eccentricity | Perihelion (AU) | V‚àû (km/s) |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| 1I/‚ÄòOumuamua | 1.20 | 0.25 | 26.3 |
| 2I/Borisov | 3.36 | 2.01 | 32.3 |
| 3i/ATLAS | >1 (hyperbolic) | ~1.4 | (see SBDB/Horizons) |

**Non-gravitational parameters (Marsden-style; units = au/day¬≤):**
- A1 (radial): 4.552e-08 au/day¬≤
- A2 (transverse): 1.770e-08 au/day¬≤
- A3 (normal): -6.198e-09 au/day¬≤

_Unit note_: If you convert to other units (e.g., km/day¬≤ or m/s¬≤), record the conversion explicitly and keep the original au/day¬≤ values as the provenance anchor.

**Interpretation (context-only):**
- Some commentary pieces (e.g., Loeb‚Äôs Medium posts) discuss what the non-grav terms might imply. Treat these as interpretation, not as the measurement source.

**Sources (measurements):** JPL-HORIZONS-BATCH-3I-ATLAS-2026-02-16; NASA-JPL-SBDB-3I-ATLAS
**Sources (interpretation):** LOEB-MEDIUM-2025-10-30-NONGRAV (T3; context-only)

**As-of**: 2026-02-17
advanced_query.user_query: What‚Äôs the orbital eccentricity and how does it compare to 1I and 2I?

ce5_practitioner_query.response:
# CE-5 Bridge: Science + Practice

## ‚úÖ Scientific Context (source-grounded)
- NASA Science notes 3i/ATLAS would reappear on the other side of the Sun by **early December 2025**.
- Some observer/press guides discussed a possible earlier mid-November reappearance, but this is **not source-grounded**.
- Observing setup (historical): morning twilight, low elongation; binoculars/telescope required depending on brightness.

## üåÄ CE-5 Framework (Consciousness Practice)
This guide respects both:
1) Scientific observation (what can be measured)
2) Experiential practice (what practitioners report)

**without conflating the two**.

### Suggested Protocol (adapt to your practice)
- 11-minute sessions (pick a consistent local time)
- Grounding first: breath, posture, or time outdoors
- Clear intent: observation + openness (no expectation)
- Post-session: journal what happened before interpreting

## üß≠ Boundary Respect
- This guide doesn‚Äôt claim CE-5 'summons UFOs'
- No prescriptive protocols (your practice, your sovereignty)
- Science and consciousness can coexist without conflation

**Sources**: NASA-SCIENCE-3I-ATLAS (observability overview); NASA-EARTHSKY-3I-ATLAS-NOV-VISIBILITY (press guide; context-only)
**As-of**: 2026-02-17

**Next steps**: Want a neutral observing + journaling template?
ce5_practitioner_query.user_query: I practice CE-5. How does Nov 11 fit into this?

fearful_query.response:
‚úÖ **Zero threat to Earth.** 3i/ATLAS will pass 1.8 AU (269 million km / 167 million miles) away on December 19, 2025‚Äîthat's 700√ó farther than the Moon. Its hyperbolic orbit means it came from interstellar space and will leave our solar system entirely. NASA/JPL confirm it poses no danger.

**Source**: [NASA JPL SBDB](https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi) | As-of: 2025-11-03 | Confidence: extremely_high

You're safe. This is a rare opportunity to observe, not a reason for concern.
fearful_query.user_query: Is this comet going to hit Earth? Should I be worried?

new_user_query.response:
# Welcome! Quick Start for 3i/ATLAS

## üî≠ **What It Is**
3i/ATLAS (C/2025 N1) is the third confirmed interstellar comet, discovered July 2025. It‚Äôs passing through our solar system on a hyperbolic trajectory.

## üìÖ **Key Dates**
- **Oct 29, 2025**: Closest to Sun (perihelion, 1.36 AU)
- **Nov 11 (first visibility) ‚Üí Nov 16‚ÄìDec 2 (optimal window)**: Post-conjunction visibility (morning twilight)
- **Dec 19, 2025**: Closest to Earth (1.8 AU, zero threat)

## üîç **Why Interesting**
- Nickel vapor detected at unusual distance
- Non-gravitational acceleration measured at perihelion
- Size estimate: ~0.44‚Äì5.6 km (uncertain; coma/assumptions matter)

## üí° **Explore Further**
Type `99` to see the full menu, or try:
- `1` for facts & timeline
- `13` for conversation starters
- `9` for consciousness preparation (if interested)

**As-of**: 2026-02-17 | **Sources**: NASA-SCIENCE-3I-ATLAS; NASA-JPL-SBDB-3I-ATLAS; JPL-HORIZONS-BATCH-3I-ATLAS-2026-02-16

**Next steps**: What aspect interests you most?
new_user_query.user_query: I just heard about this comet. What should I know?

skeptical_query.response:
Valid skepticism. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs verified vs interpreted:

‚úÖ **Verified (T1/T2 sources)**:
- 3i/ATLAS is confirmed interstellar (NASA/JPL/MPC)
- Perihelion Oct 29, 2025 at 1.36 AU (NASA)
- Non-grav acceleration detected by JPL‚Äôs Davide Farnocchia (135 km/day¬≤ radial)
- IAWN activated first interstellar defense campaign (MPEC 2025-U142)

üîç **Loeb‚Äôs Interpretation**:
- "8-9/10 on Loeb Scale" is *his framework*, not consensus
- "Technological hypothesis" is one of two competing explanations (other: natural outgassing)
- Testable prediction: If natural, expect massive gas plume in Nov-Dec 2025

**Sources**: [NASA JPL](https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov), [MPC MPEC](https://minorplanetcenter.net), [Loeb‚Äôs Medium](https://medium.com/@aviloeb) | As-of: 2025-10-31

Loeb‚Äôs claims are *partially* verified. The data is real; the interpretation is contested.
